content:
This is the funniest clash I've made so far IMHO. The fact that it is really progressive make it a real race. And the design is nice.

In fact, I've loved it so much I've wrote a solution which prints nice and shared the puzzle across more than Codingame (https://github.com/BuonOmo/coin-run). Please tell me if this bother you, in that case I'll make it private :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The testcases are very helpful, making it possible to finish in less than 5 minutes
Seems ok in reverse mode, thanks to the testcases

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's looks easy and kind of fun for reverse mode
In it's current state, I'm not a huge fan, the order is a bit random, I couldn't figure it out for 2 or 3 minutes

I don't think you have enough test cases to define the expected output when more than one of (down|left|right) are available.

In test 3, the 5th move is L, This gives the maximum possible number of moves (6). 
The rule could be "when down is not available, move left if you can" (confirmed by looking at your solution), or "move so that the output is as long as possible" (more difficult to code). From the test cases alone, it's not possible to determine which is correct.

More test cases will be added if people like the problem.

Also, is there a way to make all test cases appear in the prompt, or does it happen automatically with Reverse?
All test cases are added automatically for reverse and nothing else.

Ah I see, I was initially thinking of guaranteeing that there is only one solution (i.e. case 3 wouldn't exist), but then I thought that people (like me) might start to wonder about how to handle cases like test 3 since I can't give constraints in Reverse.

I fixed the test case to be less ambiguous, and I'll keep thinking more about other possible interpretations.

Can you clarify what you mean by a bit random?

In the meantime, I think the puzzle will definitely benefit from another simple test case inserted after #1 (maybe two more?), since #2-4 deal with special cases.
Well, the priority of down > left > right felt random
